segments.text: The people who stole the Romans often sank before they got to Rome.
Venus de Milo, for example, Victoria Soundface, there are many others.
Those are all from Seaport.
How long have you been interested in treasures from the sea?
Maybe since I was going to be an archaeologist.
All right.
But...
Of course, what are considered treasures by an archaeologist and marine geologist would not be treasures in the mind of the common people.
They're mainly interested in gold and silver.
And the old-timers didn't have very much of that.
Most of the coins of the ancient world are bronze, depending on the group.
But there's, for example, in Vasa, they found...
about 4,000 bronze pieces, bronze coins, and just one silver piece.
And the only piece of gold was a ring at the setting and fall.
So it's not treasure in that sense.
It's treasure in terms of knowledge, however.
There is such treasure off this coast, but it's hard to read it because the people couldn't write on this coast.
and in other civilizations they could write.
So that there's a vast knowledge about it.
In fact, it's even conceivable that the Phoenicians and Celts visit North America.
Those maps, the map up there shows potential track routes and places where sites have been found with writings
It can be translated from Phoenician and Ogham, which is a Celtic language.
Now, there's no treasure involved in it, gold and silver, but there's a lot of knowledge.
And these voyages would have taken place from B.C.
Not very well accepted, because people don't like that.
People preceded Columbus.
Of course, the first people to come probably came by way of Bering Strait,
It's certainly in 12,000 B.C., and probably some before that, long before that, 35,000 or so.
But the earlier ones were not very numerous, and enough will document maybe mistakes.
To illustrate it still further, along this coast here,
I got interested a few years ago in the, a lot of flint was present, piles of flint in the marshes, and flint that's used for streets and stone fences.
Turns out most of this was ballast brought by ships from England and France.
ships would come empty and ballast and go back with furs and cotton and tobacco and dump the ballast before they loaded them.
But it turns out that it probably is 100,000 tons of that flint ballast on this coast.
And several of us were interested in it together and found a couple pieces that looked like artifacts.
So one was a very nice flint core from which
It looked like chips had been struck.
We sent the cork to a British museum, and of course when they found that it was from the New World, it wasn't very popular to have Old World paleolithic artifacts from the New World.
But when the ballast was picked up from the beaches, most of it was double hand-sized.
Other people who picked it up wouldn't pay attention whether they had an artifact or not, so there are probably a lot of them on this coast.
So that's an illustration of New York archaeology only going back 300 years, maybe 400 years.
I want to ask some formal questions about oceanography.
That's extraordinarily interesting, by the way.
I'm a great believer in pre-Columbian contact.
As a matter of fact,
People don't generally know it, but when the Pilgrims came and established their village, you remember an Indian walked down the street, Swanto.
He said, welcome, Englishman.
In English.
He'd been across the ocean four times already.
And the Pilgrims were novices.
They went to Plymouth.
They intended to hit Carolinas, but they missed.
And they were afraid to go around the Cape.
And they settled in Plymouth, which had already been mapped four times and visited at least six times before by literate people.
But mapping it within four times was well-known.
In fact, it was probably the early visitors that spread the tuberculosis and other diseases that eliminated the Indians that made it possible for the pogroms to stay, which is curious.
But always before the first, there's some more
That's right.
As long as we're sort of wandering around here, I mean, have you ever read William McNeil's Plagues and Pestilence?
No, I haven't.
I don't think I have.
I suggest that to you.
Is that the one that's related to Thera?
No, this is a historical study of the impact of disease on primitive peoples and what impact plagues have had upon population spreading.
They're very serious, aren't they?
Yeah, and it's overwhelmingly important to your work in anthropology.
Of course, this was known to the early settlers.
In fact, you probably know that Hudson Bay Company gave blankets and smallpox to the Indians.
The French paid them for scalps.
I'm not sure they even had scalps before they were paid for it.
There's some debate over that, but most people think that the Plains Indians at least did not take scalps until they came into contact with it.
They got paid for it.
Got paid for it.
In returning to some sort of formal question I need to ask about oceanography,
Besides advice to students, what do you think were the most important technological advances in oceanography during your career?
Well, there's so many of them, it's hard to tell.
I remember going out on EW scripts on the cruises, and we were much interested in the flashing light echo sounder.
It didn't record, but we could read the depths and write it down at two-minute intervals.
And so, really, the first...
recording echo sounders were a great advance over the business of writing it down to human animals.
The development of seismic profiling was a very important thing.
Ewing had much to do with that when he was here before he went to Lamar.
And the early
Devices were like Ekman bottles and so forth, snappers, and so forth.
Made a great advance over nothing, but those have now been vastly improved.
It's hard to say.
It follows a logarithmic curve.
So what is the most important point of a logarithmic curve?
Sometimes the first point is more important, but it's pretty low.
And new points later on are much more expensive and difficult.
Precision timing is important.
in profiling and in lots of other things.
In chemistry, it's clear that the major advances, major technologies are ones that are adept.
Land chemistry, neutron activation, spectroscopy,
mass spectroscopy, electron microscopy.
Many things like that were just adapted to the ocean for physical oceanography.
The recording devices to record the temperature and slendium, oxygen content with depths of reinforcements.
The Nansen bottle was such a useful thing, which Nansen developed.
Nassman was a statesman, by the way, as well as being an oceanographer.
League of Nations delegate.
But I think he was at the equivalent of League of Nations at the time.
Anyway, it's such a useful device that it's held up the development of better ones that may be a detriment rather than a negative, rather than a plus in a sense.
But the buoys that are developed, the long-term buoys, are very important ones for them.

the geologists of course use so many different geophysical tools that they're best used in combination seismic profile when we do seismic profiling we occasionally use a seismic refraction with disposable sonic buoys the do make magnetics at the same time drag a magnetometer it doesn't cost anymore as long as they're going same way for gravity so we measure gravity
magnetics, acoustics all at the same time.
So a lot of these things.
Which is more important?
I don't know.
Now, finally, of course, you have to test the inferences from geophysics by drilling.
And of course, the deep-sea drilling is a big jump ahead of that.
We still don't know whether the continental rises contain no oil or not, because no holes have been drilled in it.
In the DSDP deep-sea drilling project,
They tried to avoid deep holes because they're afraid they might hit oil and verizes, and there's no way of cutting off the bit.
So now with the Glomar Explorer, or a ship equivalent to that, it can be done, but it costs about $60 million a year to operate compared to only $15 million a year for the Glomar Challenger.
And now is that more important?
It is more important now, but you had to begin and build on something else first.
Like you say, all scientists are standing on the shoulders of predecessors.
All equipment is standing on the tops of the previous equipment.
Were there any, I don't want to use the word discovery because that's too strong, but were there any theories advanced in oceanography which came as a shock to you during your lifetime?
Something that was unexpected?
Oh, sure, yeah.
For example, I'd known about turbidity.
I'd known about ripple marks in the shallow water organisms in what apparently otherwise would have been deep water.
This is in the Pliocene at Los Angeles Basin.
And I'd thought about it quite a bit, but it never occurred to me that...
turbidity currents would have been the cause.
I wish I'd thought about it, but I didn't.
That's a way to evaluate a good idea, when you wish you'd thought of yourself.
Now, of course, the same thing is true for plate tectonics.
Wegener had the general concept, but he knew the facts only from the land and not from the seafloor, and there's more seafloor.
And then, curious enough,
the magnetic work that was done off Northern California was classified as by the Navy.
And when that finally was released and studied more carefully, that showed the magnetic stripes, which is a fundamental incentive toward adding to Wegener's data left on the seafloor.
And once the general concept of seafloor spreading is made,
And you see how nice that fits in with the known areas of volcanism and the known areas of deep-sea trenches.
Again, I felt that that was a fine idea.
I wish I'd thought about it more.
Okay.
Both of those came in during the time I've been around.
Yeah.
As a geologist,

the uh there's a great deal of talk presently about about bringing minerals out of the ocean to uh possibly refurbish man's stay here on earth are you optimistic or pessimistic about that well the oil oil and gas from the sea floor now has a value of about

um about 50 billion dollars from the sea floor and uh that's more than twice the value of all the fish that are caught all the food in the ocean so there's no doubt what that's that's a very important thing for the ocean and there's probably a lot more there the bulk of it probably must still be there because
As I said, we haven't even drilled the continental rise to know what's there.
And very little drilling has been done beyond the continental shelf.
Most of the continental shelves of the world haven't really been thoroughly examined because of mainly inhospitable climates or inhospitable politics.
And so there's an enormous amount of oil still left.
But we don't know how much there is, mainly because of continental rise, which has about half the sediments of the world.
So there's no way to tell.
Now we hear a lot about the manganese nodules, but it's exaggerated and way out of line.
For example, the manganese itself is probably not worth anything.
The cost of extraction, except as a byproduct, would be too much.
But the copper, nickel, and cobalt are the valuable metals that are present in them.
And
are more concentrated in the sea floor nodules, at least the copper is, than in very many deposits still remaining on land that are being worked.
Now, if you consider the mining of the manganese nodules can penetrate the copper market 10 percent, pretty good penetration.
But these three metals
mined on land now amount to about $10 billion a year.

Now, if you could penetrate the copper market 10% and carry the nickel and cobalt with it, and there's not too much of a drop in the price of cobalt when it's produced in large quantity, then you might suppose it'd be a billion dollars' worth of metals produced from the sea floor.
Now, it would cost an unknown amount to recover them,

But if the difference between the, if the profit, the amount left over from the cost of production is as much as 10%, and that's available to the United Nations Seafloor Seabed Committee, which it wants, that's only $100 million.
Now, if you divide that amongst the undeveloped countries in the world as they want,
Assuming that seabed authority has no cost for operation, which is certainly not the case, that's $700,000 a country.
And if it's divided amongst the population of undeveloped countries in the world, that's three cents per capita per year.
It doesn't buy very much rice.
And the problem is, of course, that the cost has been...
has been put all out of all proportion.
I mean, the potential profits has been imagined all out of proportion by the people from undeveloped countries.
Not one of the undeveloped countries or any combination of all 140 of them can mine this stuff.
And it can be mined by half a dozen countries of the world, the industrial advanced countries.
So the UN wants the countries that can mine it to mine it, and for them to have the profits.
I don't think it will happen.
And if it's mined at all, it will be.
probably by private enterprise that has a contract with the governments of the advanced countries.
The United States may make unilateral leasing next year or the year after.
Can't wait forever on the United Nations.
So the manganese is not so very much.
A hundred million dollars profit is a lot for a company, but it's nothing for the world.
Now, the economy overlooked in the
resources from the seafloor is sand and gravel.
And that's about a half a million dollars, half a billion dollars of sand and gravels recovered every year in the seafloor.
Much of it's from, more than half it's probably from the North Sea, England and France, and some, and quite a lot from New York.
It's used mainly for landfill and for construction purposes, particularly in densely populated coastal regions where
The city is built on top of previously available sand, gravel, and river sources.
Now, after the sand and gravel, then you come to the heavy metals like tin and ilmenite, various titanium metals, and magnetite, iron metals.
Those have a total value of about $50 million.
And after that, you're dealing with shells and pearls.
The total value for those might be as much as 10 million.
After that, there's very little left.
There isn't any gold and no diamonds produced in the seafloor, in spite of the land nations.
And there probably never will be.
So is it fair to say you're certain and optimistic about international control?
Yeah.
But it seems like from an outsider that oceanographers are going to come more and more under pressure and stress from international law and international agencies.
Well, a period of benign neglect is helpful in that case.
For example, Brazil, 10 years or so ago, made a law saying, thou shalt not investigate our shelf.
So sure enough, nobody went there.
And I had a phone call one day from Brazil saying, unfortunately, they didn't have any marine geologists, but we trained some for them.
Well, I took one, and we gave him some training and let him learn a little bit about methods and so forth.
And out of that came a proposal, then, that we make a joint study of the Brazilian shell, and nothing muchdidn't hear anything from that for about three years.
And another phone call said, we're ready now.
Can you bring a ship down next month and start work?
And so I told them, no, because I'm involved in the work off of Africa.
And I couldn't go to the NSF to get more money to work on another area before that was finished.
So they wanted to know how much it would cost.
I said, about a million dollars.
And they said, oh, we'll furnish that.
And so they furnished them their own ship and funds and so forth, probably about a million.
And we made a general study of the sediments of the shelf and the general structure of the shelf, the shell of the structure, anyway.
And I think exactly the same thing is going to happen with other countries.
When we worked off of Africa, for example, I got permission from all but one of the 27 countries.
Not one was Guinea.
And Guinea is in a place where it's at the boundary between
low oil potential to the east and high oil potential to the north, right at the junction, the shoulder of Africa.
And I told that to a representative from Guinea.
In fact, he was the ambassador, Pliny Potentiary, from Guinea.
And he said, well, maybe you'd better come back.
And I said, well, you can't do that.
Guinea's too small.
We just simply went around Guinea, and Furryfoot may be there from the side, so the loser is Guinea.
They know nothing about what's there.
Now, of course, they can make a contract with our company to go there and get some information, but there's no one in Guinea, no geologists in Guinea who can understand it.
Have you foreseen a sort of,
development of international cooperation where people like... Unilaterally.
Unilaterally.
That's right.
For example, a couple years ago I was interested in a project to look at the Caribbean as a unit.
There are a lot of governments there, different languages and so forth, but most of them have such a narrow view that they like to have work done off their coast, but not off other people's coasts.
They want the results to be classified and so forth, so it doesn't get done.
But Columbia and Venezuela were among the most interested.
In fact, it's the most potential for new offshore oil.
But as we were going on with the proposal for that, they nationalized the American Oil Company Holdings, so we just turned it all over.
But I think that's the way it's going to be.
The countries that know the least about it are the ones that are going to continue to learn the least.
Then to stress the 250-mile limit and whatever?
Yeah.
I think marine geologists are probably in a better position than other oceanographers because their results can have considerable economic value on the countries.
And so there are many countries that...

that are that are understood but many of them don't have any money for example um dave ross next door here made a study of the persian gulf in which the iranians paid the iranian side of the persian gulf in which the iranians paid for most of the work much of the work maybe not and the saudis would like to do the same thing on their side
There are other problems about the Saudis, of course, because we have a lot of problems, public problems with anti-Semitism from the Saudis, and so it's not an easy place to work.
In fact, that's a general problem because you can't find...
very many countries that don't have an animosity against somebody.
When we worked in Africa, we had to be careful to let the South Africans off in a place where they wouldn't get scalped, so to speak.
And in fact, that illustrates it quite a bit, because I wrote hundreds of letters to African countries and people and institutions asking them to participate in the shipboard work.
And we had people, five people from Ghana and one from Senegal for me.
in spite of asking those.
There was always some reason why they couldn't come, but the name came, I think, because we didn't have people to understand much of it.
In contrast, South Africa asked, and we took eleven people from there, because the spaces weren't occupied anyway by black Africans.
And we had people from Brazil, Argentina,
Guatemala, Jamaica, many countries of Europe.
So the people who needed it most didn't copy.
And if they'd been aboard, they could copy anything they wanted to.
And they wouldn't know what to copy, mostly, but that's their problem.
So I think this sort of thing will continue, and we'll find that we can work many places in marine geology.
That's good.
You're more optimistic than I'd expected you to be as a marine geologist since continental shelves are closing off.
Well, interestingly enough, one of the ones that looks the least likely to be funded is an American continental shelf.
That's mainly because Congress has said that they'll have a federal program of exploration when we
And that, of course, will be run by the United States Geological Survey.
And the point is that they, in their innocence, think that the exploration can find the oil pools, and then they lease it to the companies which can pump them.
They forget that most of the discoveries are made during the development of an oil field.
But they'll have to wait.
That's another kind of political oceanography.
Excuse me, I caught your allergies.
I don't think allergies is a problem.
They think allergies are a problem.
I hope they're not.
I feel bad if that were the case.
Thank you.
What about government restrictions in oceanography?
Do you feel as if you're coming under more government pressure, less freedom of activity to work?
Sure.
As a result...
Those geographic labs have to have more and more people to satisfy the government regulations, bookkeeper labs and so forth.
And of course, the Office of Naval Research funding is being considerably reduced now.
And there was an amendment, I forgot what it's called.
Mansefield.
Mansefield, yeah, that's right.
I knew the state, but I had forgotten the name.
I mentioned it to somebody the other day.
So this means that you have to have an applied basis for the work, and most times the application doesn't come until far later.
In fact, I mentioned about the oil provinces here.
Same for East Asia, same for West Africa.
There's a lot of oil potential in places where it hasn't been drilled yet.
But the main of the argument is that having to do with...
who gets the revenue, not whether there's any oil there.
But anyway, NSF is carrying much of the load now.
I don't know whether it can continue, because the Congress is kind of concerned that the data should be applied immediately.
And that's a poor way of operating, because if you run out of basic knowledge, then you can't begin to apply it there.
And in a way, it's getting to where decisions about funding are kind of being based more on consensus than on principles.
Einstein couldn't be funded.
You see research then becoming more practical.
More applied.
More applied is a better word.
And then the sort of basic R&D, having less...
perhaps having less funding.

But to illustrate what happens with the so-called applied research, BLM, Bureau of Land Management, requires so-called baseline surveys in the areas where oil is going to be developed in order to know whether, if there's a pollution, how much it changed the bottom, and mainly

response to neo-environmentalist demands now the problem there is that there aren't enough biologists to make common studies of this samples can't be taken very close together it's the the value of it is zero in my opinion or a very tiny fraction of one percent above zero but the money going to that is tremendous but it's the there's little basic knowledge and the application is probably zero
